Award.AwardTitle: A Mixed-Methods Investigation into Underrepresentation in STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. The present research project is undertaken to explore the experiences of undergraduate engineering students who identify as members of under-represented minority (URM) groups. While several influences on URM students' post-secondary STEM experiences have been identified, there remain multiple under-explored aspects of URM engineering students' first two years in their programs. For example, there is an urgent need to deepen our understanding of what URM students are going through, as they are going through it, rather than simply in retrospect. In addition, there is room for further investigation into how multiple influences on their engineering experiences may be intertwined and may combine to impact students' development over the first two years of their college life. The current project helps to fill in these gaps in the existing knowledge base and will implicate ways to better support the success and wellbeing of URM engineering students in the future.

This project, entitled, Engineering in process: A mixed methods investigation into URM undergraduate engineering students' first two years, will advance knowledge within the field of post-secondary STEM education in general, and engineering education in particular, by exploring potential influences on URM engineering students' experiences and trajectories during their first two years of college. These influences include the following: pre-college influences; interactions with college faculty and peers; social cognitive factors; and engagement with STEM learning opportunities and structures. This study combines ethnographic and longitudinal survey methodologies in order to uncover (a) the details and mechanisms of complex social and individual processes as they unfold in real-time in URM engineering students' academic lives and (b) the change over time in important influences on students' success in their engineering program. Research findings will illuminate the challenge of underrepresentation in STEM, specifically engineering, by providing a more holistic understanding of the experiences of URM students during their first two years in an engineering school and relating certain characteristics of URM students and their experiences to their persistence in, or exit from, this engineering program by sophomore year. Results of this study will also implicate potential next steps to create new (or enhance existing) structures that promote not only the persistence of URM engineering students but also their wellbeing and holistic success as measured by supportive social interactions, social cognitive factors (e.g., their sense of self-efficacy), and their engagement with learning opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored the influences on engineering students' experiences and persistence during their first two years in college. Specifically, this study endeavored to answer two primary questions, stated below.   

 

 (1) What influences impact URM and non-URM students' persistence in engineering during their first two years? This question is answered with quantitative data from a longitudinal survey that was administered at three time points over students' first 2 years at college.

 

(2) Based on other observed and self-reported aspects of URM engineering students' experiences in their first two years, what types of support might further their success? This question is addressed with qualitative data gathered from repeated student interviews and classroom observations.

 

Results from analysis of survey data indicate that respondents' URM status is not statistically associated with their persistence in engineering through the first 2 years of college.  For both URM and non-URM respondents, analysis revealed several factors that are associated with persistence in engineering: pre-college factors; financial support and resources; perceptions of social belonging; social cognitive factors; extracurricular activities; and interest/ satisfaction levels.  Pre-college variables positively associated with persistence include whether students took an AP BC Calculus course, an AP physics course, received a higher score on the AP Physics test, received help from a teacher outside of class, whether they felt high school math classes prepared them for college, and whether students felt they were as prepared for college STEM courses as their peers. Financial support and resource-related variables negatively associated with persistence include whether or not students had a paying job, used non-university fellowships/merit based aid, and used private loans to pay for college. Among variables measuring students' perceptions of social belonging, the following demonstrate a positive association with persistence: whether they felt their contributions were considered valuable by STEM classmates and whether they felt their STEM faculty/TAs were supportive. Multiple variables measuring social cognitive factors (e.g., self-efficacy, outcome expectations, personal values) are positively associated with persistence, for example: confidence that a degree in engineering will offer preparation for multiple careers, confidence that this degree will make a difference in people's lives, and confidence in their ability to apply class learning on tests. In addition, participation in STEM clubs and organizations is positively associated with remaining in the engineering major. Lastly, the following variables pertaining to interest and satisfaction are positively associated with persistence: students' perceptions of how engaging STEM courses were; their satisfaction with the engineering major; and their interest in solving math problems. Although the variable for URM status is not statistically significant in this sample of students, it is nevertheless of interest that URM respondents, on average, scored significantly lower than non-URM students on multiple variables that are positively associated with engineering persistence, for example: pre-college factors; participation in college STEM clubs/organizations; and perceptions of social belonging in college STEM.

 

Recall that, relative to non-URM survey respondents, URM students score lower on factors that appear to promote persistence. Complementing these survey results, qualitative data also reveal that URM students face challenges to persistence that many non-URM students may not encounter. In fact, the qualitative portion of this project uncovers multiple marginalizing processes and interactions in URM students' STEM experiences. Combined with survey results, URM students' interviews and classroom observations suggest that there's a need for new approaches to supporting URM STEM students which acknowledge the complex and nuanced ways in which business as usual--or pervasive norms--in STEM can create challenges to persistence and promote the marginalization of URM students. A primary achievement of the present mixed methods study is the formulation of one such approach. Survey, interview, and observational data point to the potential benefits of a framework of support for URM STEM students that emphasizes support that is the following: (1) developmentally appropriate; (2) student-centered; (3) equitable; (4) and empowering. Developmentally appropriate support takes into account the life stage of diverse young adults as they enter college. Student-centered support refers to assistance which addresses students' individuality rather than using a one size fits all approach to teaching and advising, for example. Equitable support is an approach that references the (unequal) distribution of resources available to students with different degrees of privilege (e.g., financial and racial privilege). Empowering support encourages students to reject deficit perspectives of themselves, to avoid conflating their STEM academic challenges with a lack of STEM academic ability, and to transition to a greater level of independence in their learning. The utility of this four-pronged framework is in its use as a tool to foment transformation in a couple of ways: through the interrogation of STEM norms which may unintentionally marginalize some URM students; and via the implication of next steps to create new (or enhance existing) structures that promote not only the persistence of URM engineering and other STEM students but also their wellbeing and holistic success.
